titleStmt.title: The declaration of many thousands of the city of Canterbury, or county of Kent. Concerning the late tumult in the city of Canterbury, provokt by the Mayors violent proceedings against those who desired to continue the celebration of the Feast of Christs Nativity, 1500 yeers and upwards maintained in the Church. Together with their resolutions for the restitution of His Majestie to his Crown and dignity, whereby religion may be restored to its ancient splendour, and the known laws of this Kingdom maintained. As also, their desires to all His Majesties loyall subjects within his Dominions, for their concurrence and assistance in this so good and pious work.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 12 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 4 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

Together with their resolutions for the restitution of His Majestie to his Crown and dignity, whereby religion may be restored to its ancient splendour, and the known laws of this Kingdom maintained. As also, their desires to all His Majesties loyall subjects within his Dominions, for their concurrence and assistance in this so good and pious work.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE DECLARATION Of many thou≈øands of the City of CANTERBURY, or County of KENT.

Concerning the late Tumult in the City of Canterbury, provokt by the Mayors violent proceedings again≈øt tho≈øe who de≈øired to continue the celebration of the Fea≈øt of Chri≈øts Nativity, 1500 yeers and upwards maintained in the Church.

Together with their Re≈øolutions for the re≈øtitution of His Maje≈øtie to his Crown and dignity, whereby Religion may be re≈øtored to its ancient ≈øplendour, and the known Laws of this Kingdom maintained.
AS ALSO, Their de≈øires to all His Maje≈øties loyall Subjects within his Dominions, for their concurrence and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in this ≈øo good and pious a work.

div.head: THE DECLARATION Of many thou≈øands of the City of Canterbury, or County of KENT.

Concerning the late Tumult in the City of Canterbury, provokt by the Mayors violent proceedings again≈øt tho≈øe who de≈øired to continue the celebration of the Fea≈øt of Chri≈øts Nativity, 1500 yeers and upwards maintained in the Church.
div.p:
THe long lookt for Reformation of Church and Common-wealth, hath been the expectation of mo≈øt men: happy they at fir≈øt that could but put a finger, or adde a mite to this great and glorious work, or (as fal≈øly and bla≈øphemou≈øly) the work of the Lord. How forward was the holy City of London to bring forth their Trea≈øure for the advancing of ≈øo pious a De≈øigne, their Money, Plate, Jewels were not wanting; the common ≈øort of people thought we ≈øhould have had a golden Age, that it ≈øhould have been with them as in the dayes of Solomon, to have ≈øilver and gold as plentifull as ≈øtones in the ≈øtreet; their zeal was ≈øo hot, that it ever eat up many of them, they cannot recover it to this day. The mo≈øt part of the Kingdom hath been deluded with vain pretences of truth in Religion, of liberty and property, of all earthly happine≈ø≈øe that might be; they expected England to have become a ≈øecond Paradi≈øe. But what the Proverb of old, is now to our ≈øorrow found too true, the remedy of the≈øe pretenders to Reformation is wor≈øe then the di≈øea≈øe; the two Hou≈øes have ≈øate above ≈øeven yeers to hatch Cocatrices and Vipers, they have filled the Kingdom with Serpents, blood-thir≈øtie Souldi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, extorting Committees, Seque≈øtrators, Exci≈øemen; all the Rogues and ≈øcumme of the Kingdom have they
≈øet on work to torment and vex the people, to rob them, and to eat the bread out of their mouthes; they have rai≈øed a cau≈øele≈ø≈øe and unnaturall Warre again≈øt their own Soveraigne Lord and King, a mo≈øt pious Chri≈øtian Prince, contrary to their Allegiance and duty, and have ≈øhed innocent blood in this Land. Religion is onely talkt of, nothing done; they have put down what is good, and (as the Church of Rome heretofore did) they lead us in an implicite blinde way, we know not what Faith to profe≈ø≈øe. Nay, Here≈øies and bla≈øphemies condemned in Generall Councils long before Popery had any growth in the Chri≈øtian Church, are revived; and though not publickly owned by our Reformers, yet winkt at, or at lea≈øt left unpuni≈øhed. The Civill Government is doubtfull: our fundamentall Laws ≈øo much talkt of in this pretended Reformation, are now become onely the Votes of the two Hou≈øes: if they be plea≈øed to take away our lives and fortunes by a Vote, (as they did ≈øome of our dear Countreymen for performing their duty) it is Law, though we never come to triall: the liberty and property of the Subject (≈øo much contended for) is wholly theirs, we but va≈ø≈øals and ≈ølaves to their will; and their will is now our Law. There is now little mention made of the King in any of their proceedings; they voted Him long ≈øince not to be in a condition to govern: it is conjectured by us plain Countreymen, that they e≈øteem him but as a conquer'd Prince, ≈øubject now to their mercy; if he could e≈øcape with life it were well; all Power and Authority is now monopolited and confined within the verge of our omnipotent (yet mon≈øtrous) Parliament. The greate≈øt ≈øcruple is what to do, or how to di≈øpo≈øe of this heavie burden of the Kingdom, the King; if they ≈øhould depo≈øe him, or take away his life, they fear the people, becau≈øe mo≈øt of them yet take him for their King: they have (≈øince he came within their power) endeavoured to vex and grieve him, by the debarring him of the ≈øociety and comfort of his Royall Con≈øort, the enjoyment of his children, the attendance of his faithfull Nobility and Coun≈øellors, by removing his tru≈øtie ≈øervants from him, denying any acce≈ø≈øe of his loyall Subjects unto him, keeping ≈øtrict guards about him, urging him to the
≈øigning of ≈øuch Propo≈øitions, which might render him odious to his Subjects (As they have ju≈øtly made them≈øelves already) and the ≈øcorne of all Kings and Nations: and the end of all this is, to break his heart, and ≈øhorten his life; for that is the onely way to ≈øecure their own lives and e≈øtates. They would hold the people in hand, that they are labouring to ≈øettle peace in this Kingdome, to releive Ireland and keepe union with Scotland; But we under≈øtand that Scotland is not plea≈øed, Ireland to our knowledge is not releived, and this Kingdom much di≈øcontented, and mi≈øerably divided. If Peace be ≈øo neer unto us (as is pretended) why have they voted a ≈øtanding army of ≈øo many thou≈øands to the further grievance and impoveri≈øhing of the Land? Wherefore continue they ≈øo many u≈øele≈ø≈øe garri≈øons and County troopes? Why lay they greater taxes upon the people, and yet burthen them with free quarter? The charge of the Kingdom is increa≈øed, and yet they promi≈øe us ≈øudden peace: Surely they mu≈øt acknowledge, that either they expect a forain enemy, or el≈øe intend to act ≈øuch de≈øperate things again≈øt the King and Kingdom, as may ju≈øtly provoke another war here by in≈øurrection of the people. And it is very well known, that the eyes of mo≈øt of the people of this land are opened, and they fully di≈øcerne now their own weakne≈ø≈øe in being over credulous, and the wickedne≈ø≈øe of the two Hou≈øes in ≈øeducing them under ≈øpecious pretences, of Religion, Liberty, property and what not? They have deluded the Scots al≈øo with the ≈øame arguments, and engaged them in that cau≈øe of which the Scots begin now to repent, and be a≈øhamed, and are ready to vindicate the wrong done them by the two Hou≈øes, as al≈øo to re≈øtore the Kings Maje≈øtie to his ju≈øt rights, who is now impri≈øoned by them in the Ile of Wight: to which de≈øigne of the Scots ≈øignified in their late Declaration we are ready to joyne our a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and de≈øire the concurrence of all his Maje≈øties loyall Subjects within this Kingdome, as hereafter we ≈øhall more fully expre≈ø≈øe.

The cau≈øe of this ≈øo ≈øudden a po≈øture of defence which we have put our ≈øelves into, was the violent proceedings of the Mayor of this City of Carterbury and his uncivill carriage in per≈øuance of ≈øome petty order of the Hou≈øe of Commons for
hindering the celebration of Chri≈øts Nativity ≈øo long continued in the Church of God. That which we ≈øo much de≈øired that day was but a Sermon, which any other day of the weeke was tollerable by the orders & practi≈øe of the two Hou≈øes and all their adherents, but that day (becau≈øe it was Chri≈øts birth day) we mu≈øt have none; that which is good all the yeer long, yet is this day ≈øuper≈øtitious. The Mayor cau≈øing ≈øome of us to be beaten contrary to his oath and office, who ought to pre≈øerve the peace, and to that purpo≈øe chiefly is the ≈øword of Ju≈øtice put into his hands, and wrongfully impri≈øoned divers of us, becau≈øe we did a≈ø≈øemble our ≈øelves to hear the word of God, which he was plea≈øed to interpret a Ryot; yet we were unarmed, behaved our ≈øelves civilly, intended no ≈øuch tumult as afterwards we were forc'd unto: but at la≈øt ≈øeeing the manife≈øt wrong done to our children, ≈øervants, and neighbours, by beating, wounding, and impri≈øoning them, we were moved to vindicate the wrong done them, and to relea≈øe them that were impri≈øoned, and did call unto our a≈ø≈øi≈øtance our brethren of the County of Kent, who very readily came in to us, and have a≈ø≈øociated them≈øelves to us in this our ju≈øt and lawfull defence, and do concurre with us in this our Remon≈øtrance concerning the Kings Maje≈øtie, and the ≈øettlement of Peace in this Kingdome.

Fora≈ømuch therefore as the two Hou≈øes have exceedingly erred in exalting their priviledges above the Kings Prerogative, and outgone all former Pre≈øidents in Parliament, by exerci≈øing an Arbitrary power and government over their fellow ≈øubjects, have rai≈øed an unju≈øt War again≈øt our Soveraigne Lord and King, and de≈øtroyed many of the Nobility, Gentrie, and Commonaltie of the Land, have unju≈øtly murthered (though executed as Malefactors) many of his Maje≈øties loyall Subjects, ≈øome of our own County al≈øo, have ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed the true Prote≈øtant Religion, ≈øuffered all kinds of Here≈øies and Errors in the Kingdom, have impri≈øoned or at lea≈øt ≈øilenced and put down all the Orthodox C ‚Ä¢ ergy, taken away the livelihood and being of many thou≈øand Families, oppre≈ø≈øed and robbed the fatherle≈ø≈øe and widows, put grievous burthens upon the people, unu≈øuall
taxes of Propo≈øition money, Exci≈øe, &c. which former Parliaments never dreamed of: have impri≈øoned the Kings Maje≈øtie turned away his Chaplains and Servants from him, have broken the Union betwixt England and Scotland, and have rendre them≈øelves odious to God and all good men.

We the Inhabitants of the City of Canterbury and County o Kent, do prote≈øt again≈øt the≈øe exorbitant and wicked proceedings of the two Hou ‚Ä¢ es, as mo≈øt injurious to Religion, the Kings Maje≈øtie, and all his loyall Subjects, and contrary to Gods holy Word and the known Laws of this Kingdom, and al≈øo contrary to the tru≈øt repo≈øed in them by tho≈øe Countries, and Towns for which they ≈øerve. And we will endeavour by Gods gracious a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to re≈øtore Religion to its ancient ≈øplendour and lu≈øtre, relea≈øe the Kings Maje≈øtie out of thraldome and mi≈øerie, and re≈øtore him to his ju≈øt rights and power, whereby he may call tho≈øe men to account for all the blood they have cau≈øed to be ≈øhed, for all the va≈øt ≈øums they have extorted from his ≈øubjects, and the wrong they have done to him and the whole Kingdom. And in this our de≈øign we ≈øhall endeavour the pre≈øervation of the honourable Con≈øtitution of Parliament, (though tho≈øe men have abu≈øed it) and all the ju≈øt priviledges thereof, as much as our own lives and fortunes.

And we de≈øire all his Maje≈øties loyall Subjects within his Dominions, readily and cheerfully to concurre with us, and a≈ø≈øi≈øt us in this ≈øo good and pions a work, if truth in Religion may again flouri≈øh, the King may be honoured and obeyed, every man re≈øtored to ju≈øt rights, the oppre≈ø≈øed may be ea≈øed, the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed releived, and a firme and la≈øting Peace ≈øettled within the≈øe three Kingdomes, to the great joy and contentment of all the people thereof.
